I think use ByteArrayOutputStream is good as ByteBuf. Because both append bytes in memory very fast.

I tried it in my local and it seems working well. 🤔
Could you paste your code or let me know what was the problem?
I think doDelete() does not use DefaultServletOutputStream because it just calls response.sendError(HttpStatus.NOT_FOUND.code(), "Not Found"); right away. Did I miss something?
No, do you check doDelete() at inner class: ServletServiceTest.HomeServlet (ServletServiceTest.java line 477)

Ah there's another HomeServlet in the class. Sorry about that I missed. (Perhaps we should rename it to something else to avoid confusion.)
The reason that it didn't work is that it tries to write the data first without writing headers. So I think we should fix that.
If we use ByteArrayOutputStream, we have to copy the byte array twice.
But if we use ByteBuf we can just copy the data only once. If we change to use the ByteBufAllocator from ServiceRequestContext later, we can even reduce to allocate additional byte arrays.
So I think it's better to use ByteBufs to hold the data. What do you think?
The implementation will be a little tricky so just leave it as it is and fix it later. 😄

Is there any reason that you overridden methods in this class?
It seems like we can just use the methods in PrintWriter?
Method PrintWriter.write() may be call to OutputStream.write(). I will check all write methods If there is any method that doesn't need to override, i will remove code.

The allToken is always * so we do not want to specify it.
The class StringUtil is a bit complex because it's for ANT mapping. How about just using Pattern for simplicity?
We can just consider three cases:

The path that ends with *. (e.g /foo/bar/*)
Implicit mapping. (e.g *.bop)
Exact path matching.

We might revisit this to optimize later though.
Yes, I think so. We will revisit this to optimize later.
What I meant is that I think we need to remove the StringUtil class and just use Pattern in this PR. And then We revisit this to optimize it. 😆
Oh, I understand now :D. I will remove StringUtil.

nodes.bodyText: Validation on extension and mimeType?
The keys and values of mappings need validation.
IIRC, many many servlet implementations rely on these operations to load some resources such as templates and properties files, no?
Is is some sort of specification to return the Java version and OS name in this string?

Yes, I refer from https://github.com/apache/tomcat/blob/master/java/jakarta/servlet/ServletContext.java java doc. /** * Returns the name and version of the servlet container on which the * servlet is running. *

* The form of the returned string is * servername/versionnumber. For example, the JavaServer Web * Development Kit may return the string * JavaServer Web Dev Kit/1.0. *

* The servlet container may return other optional information after the * primary string in parentheses, for example, * JavaServer Web Dev Kit/1.0 (JDK 1.1.6; Windows NT 4.0 x86). * * @return a String containing at least the servlet container * name and version number */
Servlet context listeners are also an important part of Servlet specification many frameworks rely on. Are we sure we do not want to implement this? That would mean it will not work for most code.
At least some sort of minimal session support should exist. It's not easy to find a Servlet application that does not rely on this feature.

please add
//noinspection unchecked
What happened if two different servlets are registered using one servletName?
I think latest added servlet is working, because servlet registration like a Map<path, servlet>.
Ditto. please remove uncheck cast warning
ditto What happened if two different filters are registered using the same name?
I think latest added filters is working, because filter registration like a Map<path, filter>.

Then, shouldn't we raise an exception in that case?
There should be no one who wants to just override the previously set filter.
If it happens, there's likely the chance the filter is misconfigured.
But I think what happen if user want to override an existing filter? And why doesn't servlet API have removeServlet() method , removeFilter() method. Should we add these methods?
Then let's keep as it is. 😄

We should check the name is empty or not.
We can use isNullOrEmpty.
If the name is empty, we should throw an exception. * @throws IllegalArgumentException if servletName is null * or an empty String
I think servlet support empty name, it is root servlet.

https://github.com/javaee/servlet-spec/blob/master/src/main/java/javax/servlet/ServletContext.java#L769
Please refer to the Javadoc.
sessionTrackingModeSet = ImmutableSet.copyOf(sessionTrackingModes);
please just use + instead of concat as the IDE suggested.
We should not just append null when SystemPropertyUtil.get("user.name") is null.
Because this class is package-private now, we can remove public modifier from the methods which is not overriding.
Could be just "servletName is empty" in this case.
I think we can call this in the constructor of ServletRegistration.

Could remove public?
Could be final?
DefaultServletRegistration because ServletRegistration is the name of the interface?
Should we pass the initMap to ServletRegistration?
Can remove ServletRegistration.this.

return initParameterMap.get(name);

Can we remove this method and make this registration is initialized when it created?
It seems like we need to return the mappingSet that urlPatterns are added before.

yes, each servlet have one ServletRegistration to addMapping multiple urlPatterns to one servletName such as: urlPattern ("/home", "/home/user", "/home/*") map to servletName ("home").
I think, mappingSet is returned to check which urlPatterns were mapped.
Question: Don't we need to validate the value before assigning?
I see method's document: loadOnStartup may be positive, negative and zero. Therefore, I don't validate this value.

ditto: * @return the (possibly empty) Set of URL patterns that were already * the exact target of a security-constraint that was * established via the portable deployment descriptor. This method * has no effect on the patterns included in the returned set
I think returning HashSet<>(servletSecurityElement.getMethodNames()) for checking.
We can just do this in one line: this.roleName = requireNonNull(roleName, "roleName");

If the class is used only in the package we can make it as package-private.
Also, the methods are as well. We do not need the public modifier.
Could you check all classes, please?
DefaultHttpServletRequest ?

We can use SessionProtocol.HTTP.uriText() instead.
We can use SessionProtocol.HTTPS.uriText() instead.
We can use SessionProtocol.HTTP.defaultPort() instead.
We can use SessionProtocol.HTTPS.defaultPort() instead.
Please consider all other fields if we can do the same approach. 😉

The Javadoc says that this will return null if the header does not exist.
Let's just return httpRequest.headers().get(name); and add @Nullable
Do you mean we should return current (mappingSet before add urlPatterns) instead of (mappingSet after add urlPattern)?

Ah, I misunderstand the Javadoc. Then, I'm wondering if we follow what Tomcat does: https://github.com/quickhack/tomcat/blob/master/src/main/java/org/apache/catalina/core/ApplicationServletRegistration.java#L166
🤔
Is there any chances that two thread access this map?
I think two thread never access one this map instance because each httprequest run on one thread and create a parameterMap instance.
please remove this and just return ImmutableMap.copyOf(parameterMap) where it used.
I think unmodifiableParameterMap not only immutable of parameterMap but also convert parammeter value from String to String[]
Let's assign this value in the constructor and return it so that we don't have to parse every time it needs
We should return -1 if the length is greater than Integer.MAX_VALUE
Let's just do HttpMethod.POST == httpRequest.method()
We should call this only when the content type is MediaType.FORM_DATA?
serviceRequestContext.path() does not contain the query
Then we can simple do queryParams.get(name);
return Collections.enumeration(ImmutableSet.copyOf(queryParams.names()));
return queryParams.getAll(name).toArray(String[]::new);
We can build this using the queryParam. This will be expensive so we might create this one time in the constructor and reuse it.

The reason that I wanted you to put this class in this package was that I wanted to have the parsing logic here only so that we can remove the duplicate code.
Is there any reason that you cannot move queryParamsOf() in AnnotatedValueResolver?

I think, we cannot use AnnotatedValueResolver.queryParamOf() because I want to QueryParamUtil will support at future:

parse parameters from url
parse parameters from body
parse upload files from multipart

AnnotatedValueResolver.queryParamOf() doesn't support all these features.

Thanks for the explanation. 😄
I think AnnotatedValueResolver.queryParamsOf() can

parse parameters from URL.
parse parameters from body.

But it cannot

parse upload files from multipart

It's because we do not provide multipart support on Armeria at the moment. However, once we support it, annotated services and Servlet will use the same logic to parse that. Which means that we have to put the logic in the same place.
So what I recommended is, could you just copy the code into the DefaultServletHttpRequest and use it? I will send a follow up PR that removes the duplicate code. 😄
x.split(";") happend twice.

It seems like the parsing locale logic is a little bit complex. We also have to consider quality as well.
If you want we can make a separate PR for this. If you want to include it in this PR, how about referring what other frameworks do? For example: https://github.com/apache/tomcat/blob/master/java/org/apache/catalina/connector/Request.java#L3329
I will create a separate PR for this later :)
We can remove queryString and just use serviceRequestContext.query().

We do not have to use replace which is a bit heavy computation because we know that the requestURI starts with the context path. So we can do:
requestURI.substring(servletContext.getContextPath().length());

This should be null when there's no path info.
From the implementation this is always an empty string. Could you check this out by making unit tests please?
Do not have to call requestURI.replaceFirst(getContextPath(), "") here again. We already did.

URL = "/home?test=1&array=abc&array=a%20bc#code=3"

	at com.google.common.collect.ImmutableMap.conflictException(ImmutableMap.java:216)
Please add @VisibleForTesting when the method is not private to use in tests.
We can completely remove this method.
We can use httpRequest.authority() instead of getServerName() and port.
These two line can be merged into one.

contentType can be null.
We should check it before call toString() on it.
We should check if getInputStream() is called or not as we did it in getInputStream().

We can do serviceRequestContext.config().virtualHost().defaultHostname()
and this is not nullable.
Could just do serviceRequestContext.sessionProtocol().isTls()
I think this is not nullable.
Let's add @Nullable
Let's just return getTime() right away because Date is Obsolete.

This can log three times for just one header.
How about logging it after all parsing fails?
We might consider caching all this sort of heavy operation later. 😉
queryParams.getAll(name).isEmpty()
If useInputStream is true, I think we need to raise an exception.

We should return the remote port:
((InetSocketAddress) serviceRequestContext.remoteAddress()).getPort()
We can just do headersBuilder.contentType(MediaType.HTML_UTF_8);
Shouldn't this be getResponseCharacterEncoding()?
How about removing this method and add cookie every time addCookie() is called?
This does nothing. Could you use PathAndQuery.encodeToPercents()?

As Java doc said:
     * Encodes the specified URL by including the session ID,
     * or, if encoding is not needed, returns the URL unchanged.
     * The implementation of this method includes the logic to
     * determine whether the session ID needs to be encoded in the URL.

Therefore I return the URL unchanged because we have not support servlet session yet.

But we call this from encodeRedirectURL().
Shouldn't we encode it?

Yes I think so. Tomcat's encodeUrl() also just return Url append &jsessionId=.... : https://github.com/apache/tomcat/blob/master/java/org/apache/catalina/connector/Response.java . If we don't support servlet session now, I think we just return Url unchanged.
Thanks for checking. 😄
Seems like we need to use 302.
Can remove toString()
Can do just set(name, value);
Can do just add(name, value);
setLong?
addLong?

Could just call directly headersBuilder.set(HttpHeaderNames.CONTENT_TYPE, contentType);
So we don't have to call toString
We can add @Nullable and return null. Javadoc says so.
It seems like we don't override this method because it's implemented in ServletInputStream?
No, because all request data parsed to servlet parameters. I think readLine() is only useful to read a large size upload data. We don't support this case now.
If we support read(), shouldn't we support readLine() as well?
I think, we also shouldn't support read() now.

Then, is it better to just not support in DefaultServletHttpRequest.getInputStream()?
Is there any chance that content type of the request is not FORM_DATA so that the content is used directly by the user?

Is there any chance that content type of the request is not FORM_DATA so that the content is used directly by the user?

I have thought about your question before. But I have not found a solution for this problem. Does Armeria provide an API return InputStream to User without aggregate operation?

Then, is it better to just not support in DefaultServletHttpRequest.getInputStream()?

Yes, I think so.

But I have not found a solution for this problem.

I might lose a context. 😄 What was the problem you are mentioning?

Yes, I think so.

If so, let's do it. 😉

I might lose a context. 😄 What was the problem you are mentioning?

I mean: Input stream support read directly bytes data, then we can read each part of data. But if we aggregated request, I think all data bytes already read to bytes array. Therefore using Input stream is unnecessary.
ditto
This doesn't do anthing?
Could be source.isReadable()?
Could be !source.isReadable()?
Could be response.getResponseWriter().isOpen()?
Could be response.getResponseWriter().close();?
What happens to the second right? A user can do it?
Do you mean off >= 0 is right? Sorry, I think I haven't caught your question.

Yes, 2 can't be written, therefore If I want to write a download file I have to convert whole file to bytes array and convert byte arrays to HttpData. I think it use so much memory, not good. Do you have another solution to write each part of download file? Can I call tryWrite(HttpData) multiple time? Can I split download file to multiple HttpData.
If we can't write multiple time, I think write(2) should be raise an exception. Ofcourse, we need a AtomicBoolean isWritten to check response have already written. What do you think?

I think we should allow users call write multiple time.
How about caching the written bytes and write it to the HttpResponseWriter when close() or flush() is called?
Is this not supported?
ditto write can only happen once?
Do you mean we should check state isWritten ?
Because this class is not used, could you remove this?

We use of for this purpose.
ServletHttpExchange.of(...)

If dispatcher is null, I think we should return NOT_FOUND. I will add return; command here. Do you have another solution?
ctx is not used. Could you remove that?

I don't see any code calling this what is this for?

It's never null, so we don't need this check
ditto
Is it always use HTTP/1.1?
No, but FullHttpRequest interface use HttpVersion which is not support all HTTP version, and we don't use this HttpVersion information. I set correct Armeria HTTP version to ServletAPI now.

I decided to keep io.netty.handler.codec.http.FullHttpRequest because I don't want to clone all parsing APIs and decoding APIs from Netty project. I reused these APIs. I implemented servlet OutputStream, servlet PrintWriter.

We have the corresponding parsing and decoding APIs. If we don't we can add the APIs. The Netty HttpRequest is already converted to Armeria HttpRequest before it gets here and changing it back is not reasonable. We should not use that.

I add new class ServletMultipartRequest here because Armeria HttpRequest is not support multipart. I will create another pull request to fix #253 Add HTTP multipart content support and refactor this code later.
Can remove @Nullable.

+/*
+ * Copyright 2020 LINE Corporation
+ *
+ * LINE Corporation licenses this file to you under the Apache License,
+ * version 2.0 (the "License"); you may not use this file except in compliance
+ * with the License. You may obtain a copy of the License at:

+ *

+ * distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT
+ * WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the
+ * License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations
+ * under the License.
+ */
+package com.linecorp.armeria.server.servlet;
+
+import javax.annotation.Nullable;
+import javax.servlet.http.HttpServlet;
+
+import com.linecorp.armeria.server.ServerBuilder;
+
+/**
+ * A builder class which creates a new {@link ServletContextImpl} instance.
+ */
+public class ServletBuilder {
+
+    @Nullable
+    private ServletContextImpl servletContext;
+
+    private ServerBuilder serverBuilder;
+
+    /**
+     * Constructor.
+     */
+    public ServletBuilder(ServerBuilder serverBuilder) {
+        servletContext = new ServletContextImpl();
+        this.serverBuilder = serverBuilder;
+    }
+
+    /**
+     * Creates a new {@link DefaultServletService}.
+     */
+    public ServerBuilder build() {
+        return serverBuilder;
+    }
+
+    /**
+     * Add a servlet of the {@link DefaultServletService}.
+     */
+    public ServletBuilder addServlet(String path, HttpServlet httpServlet) {

nodes.bodyText: Question: Is this class from Servlet spec? or did you implement this class just for convenience?
Yes, I implement this class just for convenience.
Question: Is this class from Servlet spec? or did you implement it just for convenience?
Can remove javax.servlet.ServletRegistration because Dynamic extends it.
Question: Does this have to be Dynamic? If all parameters are set when it's added, could be just ServletRegistration?
This have to be Dynamic interface, because ServletRegistration interface don't include setLoadOnStartup() method and setAsyncSupported() method.

Yes, but it seems like we don't set setAsyncSupported as true for now. Also setLoadOnStartup(1) doesn't seem much meaning.
How about just using ServletRegistration here and
adding another method for async such as addAsyncServlet later?

Agree, Armeria has been async already. We don't need servlet async sound like that add more queue + executor thread pool. In this case servlet async make system more complicated and not good performance.

Please add static final. Also we just use ServleteContextImpl.class.
private static final Logger logger = LoggerFactory.getLogger(ServleteContextImpl.class);
Let's rename to DefaultServletContext.
Let's add these fields to ServletBuilder so that a user change the values.
After that. We can get all properties from the constructor and make all properties as final.
this.classLoader = requireNonNull(classLoader, "classLoader");
requireNonNull(absoluteUri, "absoluteUri");
Please use requireNonNull through out this PR if the parameter is not annotated with @Nullable.
checkArgument(sessionTimeout > 0, "sessionTimeout: %s (expected: > 0)", sessionTimeout)
Please validate the parameter through out this PR.

Is there any reason to make ServletHttpExchange?
We have ServletContextImpl already, couldn't we just make ServletHttpRequest and ServletHttpResponse directly?

ServletHttpExchange like a HttpExchange https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/jre/api/net/httpserver/spec/com/sun/net/httpserver/HttpExchange.html in JDK HttpServer. ServletHttpExchange store protocol information, channel or reader/writer API. I think we should separate initialization class (ServletContextImpl) and communication class (ServletHttpExchange) . How do you think?

Yes, but it looks like all ServletHttpExchange doing is just calling getServletContext() which we already have.
How about introducing it later when we find that it really needs?
Agree, I will remove it.

If we add the ServletService one by one, https://github.com/line/armeria/pull/2686/files#diff-6b0e2525eb80747c141e9fb8daa2c3adR56, we don't need this dispatcher
because Armeria server will handle the routing.
Yes, we don't need routing here. But dispatcher help us insert filter class (interceptor). I think we should keep dispatcher here.

@dominhhien Thanks for the explanation. Honestly, I'm not sure if we need this or not. If it's just only for the filter, we can implement our own logic for that. so that we can remove complicated UrlMapper and MimeMappings classes that Armeria server already handles.
Is there any other usage for the RequestDiscpatcher except for the filter?
Also, is there any chance that a user needs to use RequestDispatcher?
I think we should keep RequestDispatcher interface because it is a part of Servlet API.

There is no way to set these properties.
How about adding it to ServletBuilder?
ServletBuilder servletBuilder = ...
servletBuilder.requestCharacterEncoding(...)
...
servletBuilder.build(); // DefaultServletContext is created at this point based on the properties set so far.

Yes, I know. But I'm not sure if we should support contextPath. If we support context path, all service URLs have to concat context path. Example if context path is (/app), service URL will be (/app/welcome, /app/home) instead of (/wecome, /home) . Should we support context path? How do you think?
I think we will support context path later, context path is only useful if we want to deploy multiple apps on one armeria server.
If we decide to support contextPath. I will add setContextPath() method to ServletBuilder.

Should we support context path? How do you think?

I don't think so. 😄 Please add setters that you think a user might want to customize.
Agree, I will add setters.

Also could you add tests for the path we discussed using ServerExtenstion?
For example:
When contextPath = "" and the servletes are added to the path "/foo", "/foo/" and "".
When contextPath = "/foo" and the servletes are added to the path "/bar", "/bar/" and "".
Agree, I will add tests code.
These three properties can be here. Please imagine a situation that this DefaultServletService handles multiple thousands requests.

Please note that the contextPath could be: /x/y/z
So we should do contextPath.charAt(contextPath.length() - 1) != '/'

Probably not, because user can add servlet root path "/" or "" (It is also context path) :
sb.servlet("/", new HomeServlet())
or
sb.servlet("", new HomeServlet())
I think user should decide whether to implement servlet root path or not.

sb.servlet("/", new HomeServlet())
or
sb.servlet("", new HomeServlet())

What's the URL that a user connects to the servlet in those cases?

What I meant was what's the difference between URLs when contextPath is "/" and ""?
Isn't it http://host:port/ in both cases?

Armeria server does not support empty service path (""). But servlet support empty path. If we access http://host:port, server return http://host:port/ => Http response status is 307 (redirect) instead of 200(ok) because URL was changed. If we support both cases "/" and "", Http response status always be 200 (ok).

Armeria server not support empty service path ("")

Right, Armeria does not support the empty path so a servlet on Armeria couldn't have empty path mapping. Isn't that right?
I was thinking just adding / after contextPath when we call
serverBuilder.serviceUnder(...); because the contextPath does not end with /
so that we can just handle the servlets by just adding one DefaultServletService.
When contextPath is /foo:

if a user adds a servlet too /bar, then the url is http://host:port/foo/bar

When contextPath is "":

if a user adds a servlet too /baz, then the url is http://host:port/baz
if a user adds a servlet too /, then the url is http://host:port/

When contextPath is /:

This is an exception.

What do you think?
Yes, it's like you explained. I will fix this exception. Do you suggest another solution for this problem?

I think add available DefaultServletService is not perfect solution. It is very nice if default case return Not found with path / and users can add a customized servlet / when �they need it. What do you think?
Question: Should we allow to add a servlet after the Server is started?
Probably not until there's a demand for such feature? It'd be nice to keep the supported feature set to an essential extent.

https://github.com/eclipse-ee4j/servlet-api/blob/master/spec/src/main/asciidoc/servlet-spec-body.adoc#35--request-path-elements
I don't see any regulation that the path should not end with /.
What do you expect? Should /home and /home/ maps to the same servlet or 2 different servlets?
How about auto removing / if there is / at last of path.
What other frameworks do in this case?
I test some site: facebook, google, confluence. I see both path return the same content. I think we can do that by maps both path to one servlet by ServletRegistration.
But I not only use path variable in serviceUnder() but also use it in service() method. I think we can keep this line.
Ah, yes, forget about the comment. 😅
The value can be null, right?
How about making a separate PR for filter related code?
Can remove this it not used.
Yes, It is not used but Servlet API exists getServletContextName() method. I think we should create contextName from contextPath converting.
if contextPath is /x/y/z, servletContextName will be xyz. Is this what you intended?
Yes, but I think xyz is not pretty. I will change to x_y_z

We can set this when we call ServletBuilder.build().
Of course, the name should be changed such as isInitailized?
Let's remove this and setServerAddress.
return serviceRequestContext.localAddress().toString();
return serviceRequestContext.config().server().defaultHostname();
What is the default value for sessionTimeout?
I will set default value = 20 minutes. I think we don't support servlet session now. I will separate another PR to do this.
Seems like we don't support this yet. Let's throw UnsupportedOperationException, right now.
Shouldn't we target for 4?
No, we implement servlet 4. I will change it to 4.
extension.isEmpty()
Should add @Nullable
Shouldn't we check if the file exists or not first?

I think we shouldn't check file. Because method's target is get mime type (http content-type) from file extension instead of real file such as: .avi => video/x-msvideo . Web browser will open download popup, view pdf or play music base on mime type.
Let's add TODO
I think we don't support resource (html, css, js) management now.

Then, let's throw UnsupportedOperationException.
Also, could you check all other methods whether to throw UnsupportedOperationException, please?
Could fix this by referring one of the ServletContext implementations in other frameworks?

Yes, we can. I think we can do a simple resource management.
We need a resource directory on linux such as: /home/user/deploy/armeria_server/app/share .
When web browser send URL end with .html | .css | .js | .jpg ....
such as:
http://host:port/app/index.html
getRealPath() will return file path:
/home/user/deploy/armeria_server/app/share/index.html
then ServletHttpResponse will write FileOutputStream to web browser.

Also, we have some question:

How to read fast resource file, should cache resource file bytes on memory?
How to combine multi html file such as: template file + menu file + body file?
Should we support Java server page standard (JSP)? My opinion is shouldn't, because it's very bulky

I think we don't support resource management now. I will separate another PR to do this.

How to read fast resource file, should cache resource file bytes on memory?

Yes, we can cache the resources. Or we might use HttpFile but not sure it's going to work or not. Anyway, I think it's also deserved to have its own PR.

How to combine multi html file such as: template file + menu file + body file?

I think we don't have to consider that right now.

Should we support Java server page standard (JSP)? My opinion is shouldn't, because it's very bulky

I respect your opinion. 😄

I think we don't support resource management now. I will separate another PR to do this.

Yes, that's a good idea. Implementing servlet is really huge work. So let's break one by one. 😆
Let's remove filter related code right now.
Agree, I got it !
So you don't want to make a separate PR for the filter?

We should make the list as immutable not just for getServlets(), but also for getServletNames(), getInitParameterNames(), getAttributeNames() etc.

Totally agree!

Also, one thing we have to think about is that if the field is unmodifiable after DefaultServletContext is initialized, we can pass it when we create DefaultServletContext.
For example, initParamMap can't be changed after DefaultServiceContext is initialized

I will apply to ImmutableMap for initParamMap, other fields will keep. But I think we should use another method: �pack() instead of DefaultServletContext() constructor.
Then we can call �pack() in ServletBuilder.build() to pack any field. Ofcourse, initParamMap is not final. How do you think?
What's the �pack()? Could you elaborate more on this please?
pack() and unPack() method usually are used to encode, decode, complete header ... a object (example: ISO message) before send it. I think immutable and unImmutable may be like that.
I understood your implementation by constructor but if we have many immutable fields, I think using constructor is difficult to implement.
Ok, I got it. Then, could you pack other properties too so that they are not set after initialized?
Yes, I think so :) .

Well, you don't have to say agree all the time because it increases the comments of this PR. 😆

two spaces before =. Please use auto-formatting before you commit.

If we pass the element and path when creating ServletRequestDispatcher, we can make the fields final and we don't need the setter.

Could you add test cases that cover this logic?
Yes, I have already added test cases for this at class: ServletServiceTest line 269
What I meant was all cases like "", "/home" and "/home/". 😄
Also I wonder what happened for "" and "/".

I will add test case at class ServletContextPathTest and ServletEmptyContextPathTest . But I want to explain more about my code:
At addServlet() method: I removed / at last of servlet path before add to ServletRegistration.
Therefore whether user choose "/" or "", servlet always maps to only path ""
At getNamedDispatcher() method: I removed / at last of servlet path too before get from ServletRegistration
Therefore, whether user access URL path "/" or "", getNamedDispatcher() always return servlet maps to "".
=> "/" and "" return the same servlet.
Ah I missed that. Thanks for the explanation. 😉
